Description: Mould-made pottery lamp with a flat bowl-like body, a slightly concave base, a short splayed nozzle, and a side-handle of vertical ring-form, decorated on top with a knotted double loop pattern, separated by a central groove. The slightly concave discus has seven oil-holes, one central and six near the edge. The discus edge is decorated with a band of egg-and-dart pattern between two moulded rings. Red-brown Nile silt fabric with abundant mica, organics and white inclusions.
Curator's comments: Parallel from Naukratis in the Fitzwilliam Museum, Cambridge. Ptolemaic parallels in the Library of Alexandria Museum (unpublished, from the building site of the new library) and in Cairo Museum (CG 26509, SR5/2055). Parallel from Herakleopolis Magna (Petrie 1905, pl.56, no. R.30). Mid 1st century BC to beginning of the 2nd century AD parallel from Tell Atrib (Młynarczyk 2012, type TA 11.23). Młynarczyk, J. 2012. Tell Atrib 1985-1995. Vol. 3: Terracotta oil lamps. Varsovie : Éditions Neriton. Petrie, W.M.Fl. 1905, Roman Ehnasya (Herakleopolis Magna), 1904, London.
Bibliographic references: Lamp / Catalogue of the Lamps in the British Museum (Q574)
Walters 1914 / Catalogue of Greek and Roman Lamps in the British Museum (504)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (KD.060) (Phase 1)
